text: Words and pictures, or possibly words versus pictures with particular reference to science fiction as the subject of our discussion today, with me are Theodore Sturgeon, whose stature is a writer. We have noted in the past, the most recent collection of stories is called visions and venturers. Lloyd, big ol' writer currently on the faculty at Eastern Michigan University, and his stories of appeared widely in various science fiction magazines including the new Omnay. And he has had some 14 books published. And James are odd bird and illustrator. His work is accompanied by stories by Theodore Sturgeon, including the new visions and venturers, and in a number of other science fiction writers. He also comes from Gordon Dickson's new book Pro was illustrated by Mr. Odberg. Jim, in your view, is the role of the illustrator, particularly in science fiction, are you a crutch for the author or an equal? Well, not an equal, but certainly hope not a crutch. The illustrator, I feel, the illustrator should embellish the story. He adds to it gives it more richness and depth with the illustrations, particularly if he can work closely with the author so that he can let you see things that the author did not describe, but had in mind when he was doing the story. I mentioned Gordon Dickson was he influential in getting you started let's say in illustrating science fiction? Well, he was influential in getting me into the book illustration part of it. I've been doing illustration for quite some time, but when I got into the books, Gordon was very influential in getting the started in book illustration. What other kinds of work have you done? My founding, my basis was in industrial design, which actually works nicely in the illustration particularly the hardware and the technical end of it. You find it difficult on occasion to do something to a company of story? Not really, more it's difficult finding the real feel of the story and doing the illustration to fit the feel. The things are not difficult. It's the feeling that it's harder to find into ring crossed. There have been very few really great illustrators down through the years. I might not experience, I'm reminded of incy-wise, some people like that illustrating the Stevens and other writers, but their names simply don't stand out. One reason is that not too many of the older books actually contained illustrations or very few illustrations. So often today you want to get the impression that the illustration is a aid to the child or perhaps the semi-literate adult and getting him over the problem of reading. How do you feel about that, Mr. Stozen? We're in an interesting time. We had a long time now. We haven't had any illustrations at all. Earlier, however, they did. I can remember a turn of the sensory books that always had a froncious piece and often then he's very careful stealing cravings and woodcuts and things like that all the way through. We got away from that. We're getting back to it again and more and more you'll find interior illustrations in books and some publishers and editors like Byron Price and New York is doing a whole series of novels which are almost half-and-half illustration and copy which is very interesting. I'm going to hand upon to Mr. Advert here. He's a gymmoderate, but he really really reads what he illustrates. It happens that this copy of Vision's Inventory is fell into my hands last night with a very first time. The local B. Dalton bookstore made a special effort and got them out pre-publication and it'll probably be out generally next week but they got in a stock how I don't know. I've tried to do this myself and failed in the manager down there is really on top of it. I had my first look at it and at Jim's drawings last night there was very, very pleased. He clearly has carefully read each story and as he said the feel of it he's gotten that over very well indeed. Where I write horror he's got a horror drawing where it tends to be more mechanistic in a computer story for example. It's neat and it's laid out and you're a meter to get the feel of this story. You did not work with him? No. In the preparation. No in this case no I haven't. I've been all across the spectrum with artists working similar as not knowing who they are. No I some of them I never did find out who they were and in other cases I've written stories from a painting and editor of a by a painting he likes and say hey I got no story to go with this. I want to get into that subject in just a moment but let me ask you first of all Lloyd Bigel do you have a feeling sometimes that the illustrations have a tendency to drive out good writing perhaps? I had an interesting experience with a novel of mine called Delight that Never was which coincidentally is a novel about art and the cover painting for the paperback book was done by Kelly Freeze who was excellent and the scene that he drew for the cover painting does not occur in the book anywhere but in that scene he delineates one of the major themes of the novel beautifully. The cover could stand entirely by itself it tells us to own story which isn't a different story of my novel but it delineates a theme of the novel and with the novel of course and conjunction that it means something additional. Now if he had done a series of interior drawings on that nature the reader would have been horribly confused because again they would have nothing to do with the story even if he caught the theme in some way of what the story was about. So in your view it did add it wasn't it did add the end of those circumstances the cover yes You know there's an interesting parallel we in radio all these years have been convinced that it's an ideal medium for the imaginative as opposed let's say to film a television in other words you leave so much up to the imagination of the listener and you don't spell it out for him and translating some stories into either medium they can be done very well in radio but they're ruined the minute you see it now isn't this true to some degree of a science fiction story the minute you illustrate it you take away from the reader the opportunity to to make a concept of his own well this is true to say pictures worth a thousand words but sometimes the readers imagine his worth ten thousand words so it happens that way also it works both ways as far as art and illustration if you make a differentiation between the two I have a French addition of my novel more than human illustrated by a French artist the name is Yerar the guy is an extraordinary artist and the illustrations the pictures in the book are good art but poor illustration I mean they don't have that as you said quality of the field or the field they have is not the same as the field of the story once again when when you're when you're illustrating a story it's sometimes very important not to add too much to the story or give away the story particularly in short stories you have to be very careful not to give away the punchline or the end of the story in advance there's one envisions and ventures that when I after I read the story the immediate illustration is sprung into my mind look very nice and everything and then I wouldn't do it because it would tell the punchline at the end of the story before it would I noticed the uniform on the man in there is different from the uniform that you have in wearing so the cover I suppose is there to get you inside the story and then once you're inside the the illustrator is going to have to be much closer to the story you know the thing is is that the cover should be able to draw you in and truly reflect the story too often the cover has nothing to do with the story it's a grabber yeah that's that's essentially all there attempting to do is to put something there that looks science fictiony that will grab your eye and make you pick it up and read it and I really don't have any objections with them wanting you wanting to grab you and make you pick it up and read it but I think they should be able to do it and truly reflect what's inside the book I think that too many people sometimes get this really bad feeling because the cover and the book do not reflect one another Gordon Dixon isn't here to defend himself but I'd like to just use this as a recent interesting question is is this hour forgetful authors or no no it's just that the lady had two shirts two shirts all right that has happened you know I'm probably out of the set of open you and I insisted when they were going to put the trumpeter on the jacket of the hardcover edition that I approved the drawing first so the we had these one arm trumpet players and they drew one of those for the jacket so I very carefully went over the trumpet and made certain and exchanged letters with the artist and got that trumpet exactly the way that I wanted it and we were all pleased and several years later someone came to be and said why is the trumpeter holding his trumpet in the wrong hand and I completely overlooked the fact that all these trumpeters were missing the left arm and the artist drew it trumpeter holding the trumpet in his left arm and I'm sorry I'm sorry other experiences like that have you not I think all authors have had this kind of experience it would be a Back in the other subject there was a if I might put in one thing that helps really is that when I went through and read another book I was illustrating the author had two completely different descriptions in the size of an alien in the front and the back and I caught it where the editors had and caught it or anything because I was reading for illustrating the editors were simply reading to correct and it in that particular case I was able to catch it pointed out and they changed one so that the two of the matched. This kind of thing is awfully easy to do at a 300 page book. I've only been all-time illustrating one year. Is that right? I want to thank you all very much for discussing this very important subject of art illustration and science fiction writing. Theodore Sturgeon and Lloyd Bigger are present authors and illustrator James R. Otberg. Thank you for joining me today. Thank you.
